contextId.information: This compares the person's deeds or evil works to a spark that falls on tinder and sets it on fire. AT: "his work will be like a spark that starts a fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: and his work like a spark

contextId.information: That is, the lambs will graze there. The land will be worthless for any other use. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: in the ruins, lambs will graze as foreigners

contextId.information: The king of Assyria compares taking the treasures from the nations to a person taking eggs out of a bird's nest. This emphasizes how easy it was for him and his army to conquer these other kingdoms. AT: "My army has stolen the wealth from the nations just as easily as a man takes eggs from a nest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: My hand has seized, as from a nest, the wealth of nations

contextId.information: This compares the nations to a bird who sits quietly while her eggs are taken. This emphasizes that the nations did nothing while the army of Assyria took all of their possessions. AT: "And like a bird that does not make a sound or flap her wings when someone steals her eggs, the nations did nothing as we took their treasure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: None fluttered their wings or opened their mouth or chirped

contextId.information: A branch thrown away represents something worthless. AT: "like a worthless branch that is tossed aside" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: like a branch thrown away

contextId.information: An uproar is a very loud noise. AT: "The sound of many people, that is very loud like the seas" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The uproar of many peoples, that roar like the roaring of the seas

contextId.information: This emphasizes that the people of Egypt will be afraid and helpless when God punishes them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Egyptians will be like women

contextId.information: This compares the enemies of God's people to the heat that dries up the land. This emphasizes how much the enemies cause the people of God to suffer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: like  heat in a dry land

contextId.information: Yahweh stopping ruthless people from singing and boasting is compared to a cloud providing shade on a hot day. This emphasizes that Yahweh comforts his people by stopping those who cause them to suffer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: as the heat is subdued ... ruthless ones is answered

contextId.information: This simile emphasizes how badly Yahweh will humiliate the people of Moab. They will spread their hands in dung like a swimmer spreads his hands in water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: They will spread their hands ... his hands to swim

contextId.information: "but it is as if we have only given birth to air" or "it is like we gave birth to nothing." This is a simile that emphasizes that the people's suffering resulted in nothing. AT: "but nothing good resulted from it" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: but it is as if we have only given birth to wind

contextId.information: A "storm of hail" or hailstorm happens when hard pieces of ice fall from the sky. Here it is a simile that refers to the enemy army that Yahweh will send to destroy the people of Samaria. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: storm of hail

contextId.information: This emphasizes how weak and insignificant the invading army is before God. AT: "Yahweh will easily remove the horde of your invaders and the multitude of the ruthless ones"(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The horde of your invaders will be like small dust, and the multitude of the ruthless ones as chaff that passes away

contextId.information: These similes mean that the enemy will expect victory but they will fail because God will not allow them to conquer Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: It will be like when a hungry man dreams he is eating ... his thirst not quenched

contextId.information: The other prophets in Jerusalem are unable to hear or understand God's message. AT: "All that Yahweh has revealed is to you like a sealed book" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: All revelation has become to you as the words of a book that is sealed

contextId.information: This simile means there will be so few people left that they will be like a single flag on top of a hill. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: until your remnant will be like a flagstaff on the top of a mountain, or like a flag on a hill

contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh's breath as if it were a river of fire that will set the pile on fire. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The breath of Yahweh, like a stream of brimstone, will set it on fire

contextId.information: Here the way that Yahweh protects Jerusalem is compared to the way that a mother bird protects her baby birds in their nest. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Like birds in flight, so Yahweh of hosts will protect Jerusalem

contextId.information: This compares the king and princes who protect the people to a shelter. AT: "the rulers will protect the people like a shelter does in a storm" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Each one will be like a shelter from the wind and a refuge from the storm

contextId.information: This compares how quick and eager Yahweh's people are when they gather the spoils from their enemies to the eagerness of locusts when they gather food. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Your people gather spoils from your enemies with the same fierceness as the locusts have who devour green plants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Your spoil is gathered as the locusts gather; as locusts leap, men leap on it

contextId.information: This compares how dry Sharon is to a desert plain. AT: "Sharon is as dry as a desert plain" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Sharon is like a desert plain

contextId.information: This comparison is made to emphasizes that they are in a time of extreme difficulty. AT: "It is as terrible as the day when a child is ready to be born, but the mother has no strength to give birth to her child" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: like when a child is ready to be born, but the mother has no strength to give birth to her child

contextId.information: This speaks of how Yahweh is ending Hezekiah's life quickly by comparing it to how a shepherd removes his tent from the ground. AT: "Yahweh has taken my life away from me quickly like a shepherd packs up his tent and carries it away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: My life is removed and carried away from me like a shepherd's tent

contextId.information: The prophet compares the nations to a drop of water and to dust in order to emphasize how small and insignificant they are to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: the nations are like a drop in a bucket, and are regarded like the dust on the scales

contextId.information: The prophet compares the way Yahweh considers humans to the way humans would consider grasshoppers. Just as grasshoppers are small to humans, humans are small and weak before God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: the inhabitants are like grasshoppers before him

contextId.information: The nations whom the one from the east will conquer are compared to dust and stubble, both because they will become very small like those things and because his army will scatter them easily. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: He turns them to dust with his sword, like windblown stubble with his bow

contextId.information: Yahweh is compared with a warrior who is ready to defeat his people's enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will go out as a warrior; as a man of war

contextId.information: Yahweh compares the magicians and sorcerers to straw that burns quickly in a fire. This means that Yahweh will destroy them as easily as fire burns stubble, and so they are powerless to save Babylon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: they will become like stubble. The fire will burn them up

contextId.information: The servant compares himself with a student who learns from his teacher. Possible meanings are 1) "like one who learns from his teacher" or 2) "like one whom he has taught" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: like those who are taught

contextId.information: This speaks of the children being exhausted and helpless as if they were an antelope caught in a trap. AT: "they are helpless, like an antelope caught in a net" or "as helpless as a trapped antelope" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: like an antelope in a net

contextId.information: Here "he" refers to God's servant whom Isaiah compares to a very young tree. This emphasizes that he will appear weak. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: For he grew up before Yahweh like a sapling

contextId.information: Sheep often leave the path on which the shepherd leads them. Isaiah means that we do what we want instead of what God commands. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: We all like sheep have gone astray

contextId.information: This means shout loudly. Here "your" refers to Isaiah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_yousingular]])
contextId.quote: Lift up your voice like a trumpet

contextId.information: "A spring of water" represents a source of abundance in a land where water is precious. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: like a spring of water, whose waters never fail

contextId.information: This means that because God is not coming to them, they feel helpless, not finding the right path and despairing of the future, with no hope for a vibrant life. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: We grope for the wall like the blind ... like dead men

contextId.information: These refer to the sounds the people made because they were distressed and mourning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: We growl like bears and moan like doves

contextId.information: Here "sons" refers to the people of Israel and "you" refers to Judah, the land of Israel. This means the people will take possession of the land as a man takes possession of his young wife. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: as a young man marries a young woman, so your sons will marry you

contextId.information: This image pictures cattle going into a valley where there is green grass and water and emphasizes that God led the people of Israel and took care of them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: As the cattle that go down into the valley ... rest

contextId.information: This possibly emphasizes how easily God's presence would have caused the mountains and the people to tremble. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
contextId.quote: as when fire kindles the brushwood, or the fire makes water boil

contextId.information: A "menstrual rag" is a cloth that a woman uses during the time of month when she bleeds from her womb. This means all their attempts to please God fail. This sentence was meant to be shocking. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: and all our righteous deeds are like a menstrual rag

contextId.information: This means their sins, as a community, are the reason for their failure. Isaiah compares the iniquities to the wind as the force for their suffering Yahweh's punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: our iniquities, like the wind, carry us away

contextId.information: "Tender grass" grows fast and strong and compares to the health and vigor of God's faithful people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: will sprout like the tender grass
